qas.question: Which group of scientists began to support evolutionary ideas?
Which powerful religious institution was a big part of scientific study in the 19th century?
What was the general opinion about transmutation of species in the 19th century?

answers.text: Ideas about the transmutation of species were controversial

qas.question: How did the majority of science see humanity in relation to animals in the 19th century?

answers.text: that humans were unique, unrelated to other animals.

qas.question: Which theology did everyone agree science was a part of in the 19th century?

context: Various evolutionary ideas had already been proposed to explain new findings in biology. There was growing support for such ideas among <a0_0>dissident anatomists<a0_0/> and the general public, but during the first half of the 19th century the English scientific establishment was closely tied to <a1_0>the Church of England<a1_0/>, while science was part of <a4_0>natural theology<a4_0/>. <a2_0>Ideas about the transmutation of species were controversial<a2_0/> as they conflicted with the beliefs that species were unchanging parts of a designed hierarchy and <a3_0>that humans were unique, unrelated to other animals.<a3_0/> The political and theological implications were intensely debated, but transmutation was not accepted by the scientific mainstream.
